newCaseBoxplotHeaderHTML.html: How to interpret these charts: The bar across the middle of the box gives the median of all counties in Massachusetts on that date. Half the counties fall within the box, a quarter above it and a quarter below it. Dots in a horizontal line near the top of the graph are not real data, but mean there is a data point at that level or higher (if the graph were scaled to show everything, the interesting part of the graph would be all squished at the bottom)

newCaseHeaderHTML.html:
Trends of new cases

We are hoping to see a steady downward trend of new cases.

newDeathsBoxplotHeaderHTML.html: How to interpret these charts: The bar across the middle of the box gives the median of all counties in Massachusetts on that date. Half the counties fall within the box, a quarter above it and a quarter below it. Dots in a horizontal line near the top of the graph are not real data, but mean there is a data point at that level or higher (if the graph were scaled to show everything, the interesting part of the graph would be all squished at the bottom)

newDeathsHeaderHTML.html:
Deaths

The number of deaths from COVID-19 is unlikely to reach zero, but the fewer the better.

In counties with small populations, such as Dukes County, a few deaths -- not to minimize their importance -- can make the statistics jump a lot from day to day.

A 7-day moving average often shows trends more clearly.

Without averaging, states which do not report on Sundays, e.g., make the data look less uniform than it is.

If two or more selected counties have identical graphs (e.g. zero deaths) for the selected time period, the last one drawn will hide the other. If no graph is shown for a particular county please try again, selecting only it.

summaryHTML.html:
US

  • Confirmed new cases: 42 daily per 100,000 population
  • Growth trend of confirmed new cases: 0.352% per day
  • Estimated new cases: 59 daily per 100,000 population
  • Growth trend of estimated new cases: 0.285% per day

testGBoxplotHeaderHTML.html: How to interpret these charts: The bar across the middle of the box gives the median of all states on that date. Half the states fall within the box, a quarter above it and a quarter below it. Dots in a horizontal line near the top of the graph are not real data, but mean there is a data point at that level or higher (if the graph were scaled to show everything, the interesting part of the graph would be all squished at the bottom)

testGrowthHeaderHTML.html:
Trends in Testing

The data used for this tab is not updated as regularly as the data for cases and mortality, and is not always reliable. Uneven updates can result in numbers which change the scale so much that the resulting chart is unreadable. To prevent that, these graphs do not display data which is far outside the range of the bulk of the data. Dots along the top or bottom of the chart are not real data.

Data displayed here can vary rapidly depending on local outbreaks and testing requirements

Half the counties fall within the box, a quarter above it and a quarter below it. Dots in a horizontal line near the top of the graph are not real data, but mean there is a data point at that level or higher (if the graph were scaled to show everything, the interesting part of the graph would be all squished at the bottom)

totalCaseHeaderHTML.html:
Trends of total cases

Let's hope total number of total cases curve continues to flatten.

A 7-day moving average often shows trends more clearly.

Without averaging, states which do not report on Sundays, e.g., make the data look less uniform than it is.

Half the counties fall within the box, a quarter above it and a quarter below it. Dots in a horizontal line near the top of the graph are not real data, but mean there is a data point at that level or higher (if the graph were scaled to show everything, the interesting part of the graph would be all squished at the bottom)

totalDeathsHeaderHTML.html:
Deaths

By the present time, these totals change very slowly. Don't expect to see much change in this plot.

If two or more selected counties have identical graphs (e.g. zero deaths) for the selected time period, the last one drawn will hide the other. If no graph is shown for your county please try again, selecting only it.

vaccHeaderHTML.html:
Vaccinations, People Fully Vaccinated

Vaccination data is shown by percent of state or of US as a whole.

Highest People Fully Vaccinated rate: Puerto Rico with 63.9 percent

Next highest rate: Massachusetts with 62.3 percent

Lowest People Fully Vaccinated rate: Alabama with 38.1 percent

Next lowest rate: Louisiana with 40.8 percent

Note that 'Total Doses' will be above 100% when close to 50% of the population has had a second dose!
